bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 7, 1900

div1.p: Lazear writes about family plans. He explains the work of the investigative board and is glad that Reed will be its leader.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 7, 1900
div1.p:
I was glad
to get your letter from
New York and have
been expecting one from
Hatley every day. I hope
you are having cool weather
at Hatley. Mabel writes
that it has been very
hot at Brookline.

Here it has been delightful.
No rain for a week
and not too hot. Always
cool at night.

There is yellow fever at
the town of Marianao
near here but we
expect no invasion
of the Camp. Nearly
all the cases have
been Americans living
in Cuban houses.
which are of stone
and very damp.

There will probably
be more or less in
Havana this summer
but that will not
affect us here. The
soldiers are not
allowed to go today of these towns.
The meeting you noticed in the paper
is a board to investigate diseases
of Cuba. It means a long piece
of work, a year or two probably
and very likely some travelling
about the island. Drs Reed
and Carroll will be here in two
weeks. Dr Reed is a very well
known man and I shall
be glad to have him here.
Let me know all about your
health and how Tom Brown's
treatment affected you. Don't
starve yourself.
